metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

text_structure.notes: Chapter breaks identified during kernel creation

structure_detection.notes: 10 numbered chapters detected from table of contents

exposition.rationale: Chapter 1 establishes the isolated world of the Blackwood sisters, introducing Merricat's distinctive voice, the family's tragic history, and the hostile relationship with the village. It sets up the fundamental dynamics of their protected domestic sphere and hints at the dark past that shapes their present existence.

rising_action.rationale: Chapter 5 represents the peak of rising tension as Cousin Charles has fully infiltrated their home and disrupted their carefully maintained equilibrium. Merricat's escalating desperation and magical thinking intensify as she realizes Charles threatens to permanently alter their world, leading directly to her decisive action in the climax.

climax.rationale: Chapter 7 contains the fire that Merricat starts, which serves as the dramatic turning point of the novel. This act of destruction represents Merricat's ultimate rejection of Charles and the outside world, transforming their house and lives irreversibly and leading to the violent confrontation with the villagers.

falling_action.rationale: Chapter 8 depicts the immediate aftermath of the fire and the villagers' violent destruction of the house and its contents. The sisters flee to hide in the woods, Uncle Julian dies, and the full consequences of Merricat's actions unfold as their old life is literally and symbolically destroyed.

resolution.rationale: Chapter 10 establishes the sisters' new existence in their transformed house, now truly isolated from the world behind barricades and boards. Their acceptance of this new reality, with food offerings from guilty villagers, represents the final thematic resolution of their complete withdrawal from society into their own protected realm.

voice.pov_description: First person narration from Merricat's perspective throughout
voice.focalization_description: Limited to Merricat's internal perception and understanding

structure.plot_architecture_description: Single plot focusing on the Blackwood family isolation and transformation

voice.tone: Dark fairy tale whimsy masking underlying menace and isolation

device_mediation.summary: Literary devices accumulate gradually to create transformation from gothic horror setup to fairy tale resolution, with Merricat's unreliable narration and magical thinking mediating reader understanding of isolation, complicity, and the creation of protective fantasy

micro_devices.name: Metaphor
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: our house was built up with layers
micro_devices.effect: Presents the house as sedimentary, weighted by history and tradition

micro_devices.name: Simile
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: like a flock of taloned hawks
micro_devices.scene: Narrator's fear of village mothers attacking
micro_devices.effect: Creates vivid image of perceived threat and reveals narrator's paranoid mindset

micro_devices.name: Motif
micro_devices.scene: Narrator's game metaphor for shopping trips
micro_devices.effect: Establishes recurring game imagery that frames social interaction as dangerous play

micro_devices.name: Unreliable Narrator
micro_devices.scene: Merricat tries to convince herself and Constance that Charles isn't real
micro_devices.effect: Reveals Merricat's psychological denial and magical thinking as coping mechanisms for unwanted change

micro_devices.name: Foreshadowing
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: that Thursday was going to be the last day
micro_devices.scene: Merricat reflects on Constance making spice cookies, noting no one knew it would be the last day
micro_devices.effect: Creates ominous anticipation and hints at the climactic destruction to come

micro_devices.name: Symbolism
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: I twisted the winding knob backward until there was a small complaining crack
micro_devices.scene: Merricat deliberately breaks their father's watch that Charles had started
micro_devices.effect: The broken watch symbolizes Merricat's attempt to stop time and Charles's intrusion into their lives

micro_devices.name: Juxtaposition
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: it was a good house, and nearly clean
micro_devices.scene: Merricat looks at the house with love despite the chaos Charles has brought
micro_devices.effect: Contrasts Merricat's perception of home as sanctuary with the reality of conflict within

micro_devices.name: Dramatic Irony
micro_devices.scene: Charles asks if Constance killed Uncle Julian after his death
micro_devices.effect: Reader knows Merricat was the poisoner, creating tension as blame shifts toward Constance

micro_devices.name: Situational Irony
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: We're the firemen, we got to put it out
micro_devices.scene: Fireman explains why they can't let the house burn
micro_devices.effect: Highlights the absurdity that those meant to protect become the catalyst for destruction

micro_devices.name: Personification
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: The house seemed to shiver when she opened the door
micro_devices.scene: Constance opens the damaged kitchen door the morning after
micro_devices.effect: Gives the damaged house human vulnerability, emphasizing the violation and trauma

micro_devices.name: Verbal Irony
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: The least Charles could have done was shoot himself
micro_devices.scene: Constance commenting on Charles after his final departure
micro_devices.effect: Her darkly humorous suggestion reveals complete resolution of any lingering attachment to him

micro_devices.name: First-Person Narration
micro_devices.anchor_phrase: I will go on my winged horse
micro_devices.scene: Merricat playfully promising to gather supplies for Constance
micro_devices.effect: Maintains Merricat's distinctive voice while showing her contentment in their new life
